content.rendered:
This week turned out to be an unplanned male-appealing, male-focused, male-centered set of identities with work from Melbourne, London, and Adelaide.

Traveller by The Company You Keep

One of the hardest tricks to pull is to appear to NOT be clever by being overly clever. The logo for Traveller, an espresso bar in Melbourne run by Seven Seeds, is the image of a shoe on the move. You know… it’s traveling. It’s such a simple and clever idea it almost passes for dumb. The execution by Melbourne-based The Company You Keep is delightful, in a pasty green and off-white color palette and a modest dose of playful typography. Americans might clamor for a politically-correct alternate or complementary version with a woman’s shoe, though. See full project.

Cemento by Design by St

“Stylish, brutalist and robust.” That’s how I like most of my things, from burgers to television series to coffee and that’s how London-based Design by St describes the new identity for Cemento, the UK distributor of an Italian concrete veneer for wall panelling and furniture. Similar to Traveller above where name and image have a perfect relationship, here you read the name and then see that “C” and, bam, Cement! Thick, heavy, solid cement. In combination with plenty of white space and Avant Garde the identity achieves a fashionable, high-end feel so that it doesn’t look like any cement mix you could get at Home Depot. See full project.

Delectaballs by Black Squid Design

If you giggle uncontrollably like a 12-year-old when you watch Schweddy Balls on NPR’s Delicious Dish then the naming, identity, and tone of voice for Delectaballs, a meatball truck in Adelaide, will have you bawling of delight. Designed by local firm Black Squid Design the identity is crude, humorous, and unapologetically so. Perhaps it’s a little too much but how can you not love a drawing of a meatball with legs and shoes running around. Learn all about David’s balls. See full project.
